content.description: Good edges in a horizontal crack leads to fun face climbing with good holds. Wasn’t sure of the grade so if anyone knows the info about this route it’d be appreciated. Felt .10- ish.
content.location: On the face just left of a crack/broken band. Left of the .10d.

climbs.name: Tortured Screams
climbs.fa: Paul Moore, Shane Willett, Mark Nakada 1995

content.description: Climb up a 15 foot vertical face on jugs past two bolts onto a large ledge. Go to the right of the large overhang directly above the starting bolts. Pull over the right side of the roof on jugs to a lower-angled face above. Continue on jugs and positive edges to the chains.
content.location:
Located on the left side of

Stone Garden

. The first two bolts are found on a vertical face below a large ledge, which is in turn below a roof.

climbs.name: Tension and Stress
climbs.fa: Paul Moore, Shane Willet, and Mark Nakada 1995

content.description: Start in the same corner as Ceremonial Execution, but branch left at the large ledge above. Juggy roof moves to good slab climbing conclude the pitch. Shares anchors with Ceremonial Execution.
content.protection: 9 bolts + anchors. Some gear (1-3") might be useful before clipping the second bolt.
content.location: Right in front of you as you approach the area. Right of Tortured Screams and left of Blah Blah Blah.

content.description:
This is a cool, sligtly overhung offwidth - squeeze chimney with a few good edges to help you up. I did this left side in with an armbar, but there's lots of options.

Quite dirty.   This feels more worthy of a route grade, and I'd say it's 5.9 offwidth, maybe even 5.8.  It's a grunt but the face features and ledges keep it from 5.10
content.location: About 100 yards South of the memorial plaque boulder, hiding in some trees. Located on same boulder as "saffron & sensimilla" crack.

climbs.name: Sessions
climbs.fa: Shane Willet, Fred Henion, Jonathan Knight, 1995

content.description: Underneath the huge overhang at the Stone Garden there is a ledge that can be reached by walking/scrambling up some loose dirt to the right of it.  Once on the ledge there is a bolt that can be clipped.  This marks the start of the route.  Sessions follows the bolts that go furthest left of the climber.  Sessions reminded me of climbing an upside down stair case.  Very fun and substained climbing!

This is a real fun, tall finger crack - layback, with an easy mantle on good hand jams at the top. I really had to clean this one, and felt it was an FA, until I saw an obscure video of someone before me and saw this name on the High Uinta Bouldering FB page.

Regardless, real fun relatively tall problem.
content.location: This is about a hundred yards south from the plaque boulder, in a nice dihedral near the mushroom crack.

content.description: This is underneath Sessions, there is a plaque on the boulder dedicated to paul moore

This classic route is a route worth obsessing over. It climbs steeper than sessions with longer reaches to even better holds. The route is sustained, so climb fast or else the steepness will catch up to you and you'll find yourself struggling to hold onto jugs.

Edit for those that couldn't understand the winch start:

Either clip the first draw and pull up to start the route, traverse in from the start of sessions, have a buddy get down on his hands and knees to boost you up to start, rebuild the giant rock pile that was once at the base, or do the wicked hard boulder problem that changes the grade.
content.protection:
Rope, harness, quickdraws, and belayer needed. Shoes, chalk, and forearm muscles recommended.

For better clipping stances and less rope drag at the top due to the steep nature of the route, double up your draws or use 60cm/ 24in slings.
content.location: Starts to the left of sessions, follows it's own bolt line, and ends on the same chains. The start used to have a large rock used to reach the starting holds, the rock is now gone, but occasionally a stack of smaller rocks can be found under the start (another way of starting this route has been described as a winch start using the first draw to pull up), or if you're wicked strong figure out the bouldery start.

content.description: Easy climbing to a no hands rest, chill out for a minute and blast straight into a cool boulder problem with crimps, side pulls, and a final throw to a jug! If the crux of this route were a boulder problem in Joes it'd be a mega-classic! 4 star boulder problem! Mad respect to anyone that's able to onsight this sick rig!
content.protection: Quickdraws to chains with biners thanks to the FA
content.location: This route is one route to the right of "here today, tomorrow, and next week" and starts to the right of the arete following the bolt line that trends leftward to the small overhang.

content.description:
A nice route with decent protection; this traditional line climbs solid rock up a long, steep face. Quality quartzite and horizontal edges are abundant, the crux comes early at a thin spot using small crimps. Most climbers will find the climbing to be thoughtful and exciting with optimal protection.

Pull through an easy roof to a steep and varied face, follow the path of least resistance and protection to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Draws, slings, and gear up to 1 inches. Cams and stoppers seemed to be used almost equally. Two-bolt chain anchor.
content.location:
Found in the center of the

Stone Garden

,

Next Year

is on the left-side section of the wall that features

Sessions

. It lies just right of the bolted

The Gentleman Who Fell

.

climbs.name: Married to the Obsessed
climbs.fa: Paul Moore, Shane Willett, Mark Nakada 1995

content.description:
Burly start using an undercling, crimps, and sidepulls to clip the first bolt, then jugs for a bit.

Above the fifth bolt awaits the crux - an interesting problem dependent on feet, opposition, and reach. Two mantles onto ledges above the crux are followed by easier cruising to the chains.
content.location:
Located right of the huge overhang containing

Sessions

. There is a low, overhanging roof (about chest height) with a black-painted bolt on the right side (this is the start to

Charm

).

Married to the Obsessed

is the route immediately left of this roof.

content.description: Starting on two good sized crimps in middle of the face
Great overhung climb with some fun moves getting to the chains. Heard the bolt on the face below the chains was added later.
content.location: Shares the first bolt of Sessions and then moves right and eventually onto the face up high.

content.description: Easy, but engaging climbing to a fun, thin, technical stopper crux that leads to a glory horizontal crack jug and finishes on a good clipping hold just left of the chains! This route has proven to be a hard onsight for climbers of all grades! Good luck!
content.location: Starts on the same hold as November Shivers, but immediately goes right and sticks to it's own bolt line. Just left of Laborious

content.description:
Follow the first three bolts of Sessions then split right. Increasingly difficult moves lead to a right facing layback. Burl past this this feature using power or kneebars, until you can grab a large left hand pinch. Then crimp your way over the roof(crux) to better holds. Follow a ramp out right to the chains.

Great movement, nice rock, and cool grips.

6 bolts + chains. Use a long runner under the roof.
content.location: Start on Sessions and head straight up and over the prow. Between Sessions and Lost Souls.

climbs.name: Laborious
climbs.fa: Paul Moore, Shane Willet, and Mark Nakada 1995

content.description: Bolted face left of Fear of Gear.  Crimpy bouldery start leads to long reaches with good holds.
Left and around the corner of fear of gear.  Starts on a face left of a chimney.  Fun moves and some good jugs in the right spots, be careful getting to the second bolt.

This is a fun face climb that is located just right of F.Y.D(10c).  It is the second route to the right of the obvious crack line Fear of Gear(7).  The lower portions of the climb are very easy, but the difficulty increases near the top.

climbs.name: The Gentleman Who Fell
climbs.fa: Shane Willet,, Paul Moore, Make Nakada 1995

content.description: Great steep jug haul, a great warm-up for the area.   Lots of fun moves. Had a bit of a Hollow Man flashback for me.
content.location: As you approach the wall from the trail you will see that a major portion of the wall is overhanging.  Just to the left of the giant overhang you will see a chimney.  The route climbs the bolts right of the chimney.

content.description: This climb is located on the far left of side of stone garden, it's on a wall that can be reached from a scramble up some loose dirt just left of the main crag. Fear of Gear goes up the obivous crack in the middle of the wall.  the route protects well and has some very fun moves and some good jamming
content.protection: Mid sized cams, a #4 Camalot can be used.

climbs.name: F.Y.D.
climbs.fa: Mark Nakada, Shane Willet, and Paul Moore 1995

content.description:
A slab route with good edges that wanders right at the top.  It sits at the left end of the Stone Garden (when looking at the wall) between the obvious route

Fear of Gear

and a large flake in the corner.  It is currently the bolt line between Fear of Gear and

Grief

.  The crux seemed to be a mantle near the top, but some chalked holds indicated the mantle may be bypassed by climbing left.
content.protection: 6 bolts + 2 anchor bolts with rap hangers.

content.description:
Exodus

starts on the slab with a bolt. Climb up past some choss untill you're under the 1st roof. Power-up through the roof on good crimps and get your feet up. Continue up to the 2nd roof, put some gear and make an exciting traverse right. Finish up the face to a bolted anchor.

Exodus is mostly bolted (9 bolts) but you'll want to place a few pieces of gear as well (small tcu's to #1 cam).
content.protection: 9 bolts plus small tcu's to #1 cam.
content.location: Located just right of Next Year.

content.description:
Shares first two bolts with

Tortured Screams

to the ledge. Two more bolts protect the steep horizontal jugs to the lip, after the lip find easy protection in the horizontal cracks (tri-cams and hexes work well) on easier low angle climbing.
content.protection: 4 bolts plus some gear for the slab. Metolious rap bolts up top.

climbs.name: Cries of Impending Doom
climbs.fa: Shane Willet, Paul Moore, Mark Nakada, Summer 1995

content.description:
Continuous pulling over edgy terrain! Fight the Pump!

Cries of Impending Doom

has a difficult and awkward start. Begin steep, leaning right on solid rock supplied with good edges. Pull through on some great holds and nice stances clipping well placed bolts. Follow the thinning line to a bulge and be prepared for a surprise. The crux sits here about half way up the route, tricky and sparse, most

Cries

are heard here. Save your endurance, it'll be needed. Blast by the crux and enjoy a relatively moderate finish to the anchor.
content.location:
Cries of Impending Doom

is currently the third route in from the right side of

The Stone Garden

and sits right of

Charm

climbs.name: Ceremonial Execution
climbs.fa: Paul Moore, Shane Willett, Mark Nakada 1995

content.description: Start up a 10 foot vertical face using layback moves and clip the first bolt just below a large ledge. Get onto the ledge and look for the next bolt to the right of the roof directly above the first bolt. Overcome the roof using jugs and good feet and then cruise on positive edges and jugs to the chains.
content.location:
Located 30 feet to the left of a chimney, which is in turn located to the left of the huge overhang containing

Sessions

. There is one bolt below a large ledge on the vertical face that is the right side of a wide open-book dihedral.

content.description: Bloody Knuckles climbs just to the left of The Birds From Hell on the far right side of Stone Garden.  The climbing is pretty straight forward face climbing.

climbs.name: Blah, Blah, Blah
climbs.fa: Shane Willet,, Paul Moore, Make Nakada 1995

content.description: Fun move pulling the small roof.  You have the choice to use the small open book, or move right of the second bolt.  Couple reachy moves and a great undercling at the top.
content.location: As you approach the wall from the trail you will see that a major portion of the wall is overhanging. Just to the left of the giant overhang you will see a chimney. The route climbs the bolts right of the chimney.

content.description: The Birds From Hell is the furthest right climb at Stone Garden.  The rock that this route is on is a little above and about 100ft? to the right of Sessions.  The climbing is pretty straight forward face climbing, with the crux at the top.
